G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: This Court has **subject matter jurisdiction** over this action pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, §19**, as this claim for damages does not exceed the jurisdictional monetary limit of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a71 and 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the **Newton District Court** pursuant to **G.L. c. 223, §§1 and 2**, because the acts and omissions complained of occurred within this judicial district and Defendant resides here.

Newton Revised Ordinances, Ch. 3, \u00a7.proposition: The City of Newton prominently posts signs in the park stating that all dogs must be kept **on a leash** at all times, in accordance with **Newton Revised Ordinances, Ch. 3, §21**, and relevant Massachusetts law permitting municipalities to regulate animals (**G.L. c. 140, §§173–174B**).

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7\u00a7173\u2013174B.proposition: The City of Newton prominently posts signs in the park stating that all dogs must be kept **on a leash** at all times, in accordance with **Newton Revised Ordinances, Ch. 3, §21**, and relevant Massachusetts law permitting municipalities to regulate animals (**G.L. c. 140, §§173–174B**).

Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86, 88 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person who owns or controls a dog has a **duty to exercise reasonable care** to control the animal and prevent foreseeable injury to others.
Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86, 88 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion is interpreting and applying Massachusetts’ strict statutory liability for dog bites under G.L. c. 140, § 155, focusing on who qualifies as an “owner or keeper” and on pleading/joinder issues. It does not discuss any common-law duty of reasonable care, negligence standards, or foreseeability; liability attaches by virtue of ownership/keeping, not failure to exercise reasonable care. Accordingly, it does not support the claimed proposition about a duty to exercise reasonable care to control a dog.
Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86, 88 (19.relevant_excerpt: G. L. c. 140, § 155, provides: “The owner or keeper of a dog shall be liable in tort to a person injured by it in double the amount of damages sustained by him.” … Here if Agostino and Rachele jointly were both owners and keepers of the dog, a liability would be established.

Mahan v. Reynolds, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 235.raw_text: Mahan v. Reynolds, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 235, 239 (2005)
Mahan v. Reynolds, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 235.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person who owns or controls a dog has a **duty to exercise reasonable care** to control the animal and prevent foreseeable injury to others.
Mahan v. Reynolds, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 235.case_name: WHTR Real Estate Ltd. Partnership v. Venture Distributing, Inc.
Mahan v. Reynolds, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 235.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text concerns a commercial lease dispute, sublease consent standards, evidentiary issues, and attorney’s fees. It does not address dog ownership, animal control, negligence duties related to animals, or any analogous tort principle. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for a Massachusetts duty-of-care rule regarding owners or controllers of dogs.

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7\u00a7173\u2013174E.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to comply with municipal leash ordinances and to maintain control of his dog to prevent harm.

Salvati v. Franklin, 91 Mass. App. Ct. 4.raw_text: Salvati v. Franklin, 91 Mass. App. Ct. 428, 433 (2017)
Salvati v. Franklin, 91 Mass. App. Ct. 4.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to comply with municipal leash ordinances and to maintain control of his dog to prevent harm.

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 359 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: Violation of a safety ordinance constitutes **evidence of negligence** under Massachusetts law.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the Massachusetts rule that violation of a statute like G.L. c. 138, § 69 does not constitute negligence per se but is only “some evidence” of negligence as to the harms the statute is intended to prevent. That is precisely the proposition that a safety-related statutory/ordinance violation constitutes evidence (but not conclusive proof) of negligence under Massachusetts law.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se… Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.raw_text: Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 500 (1968)
Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.proposition: Violation of a safety ordinance constitutes **evidence of negligence** under Massachusetts law.
Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: The court expressly states the general Massachusetts rule that violation of a criminal statute is some evidence of negligence as to the harms the statute was intended to prevent. Although the statute at issue is a liquor law rather than a “safety ordinance,” the principle is stated broadly and directly, making the case proper authority for the evidentiary effect of statutory/safety-ordinance violations in negligence actions under Massachusetts law.
Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: “A violation of a criminal statute is some evidence of the defendant’s negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp. 267 Mass. 501, 516. Baggs v. Hirschfield, 293 Mass. 1, 3. Falvey v. Hamelburg, 347 Mass. 430, 434.”

Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass. 7.raw_text: Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass. 790, 794 (1987)
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass. 7.proposition: Defendant’s negligent conduct was the **proximate cause** of Plaintiff’s injuries.
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass. 7.case_name: Solimene v. B. GRAUEL & CO., KG
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses causation (including proximate and intervening cause) and affirms that questions of causation are generally for the jury. Here, the jury found Grauel negligent, the court rejected the superseding cause argument, and it held that the plaintiff sustained her burden of proving that Grauel’s negligence caused her injury. While the case focuses on intervening/superseding causation and design defect, it does affirm that defendant’s negligence was a sufficient legal (proximate) cause of plaintiff’s injuries to sustain liability.
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: Generally, questions of causation, proximate and intervening, present issues for the jury to decide. … The jurors determined that any negligence of the employer was not a superseding cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. … The plaintiff has the burden to show that Grauel’s negligence caused her injury. … The plaintiff sustained her burden by proving that there was a greater probability that the harm which occurred was due to causes for which Grauel was responsible.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.proposition: The harm suffered by Plaintiff—physical injury, medical expenses, and lost wages—was a **foreseeable risk** of Defendant’s negligent conduct.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.support_reasoning: The court explicitly grounds the existence of Kask’s duty in the foreseeability that a violent, mentally unstable person with unsupervised access to the home would take a gun and use it to inflict physical harm, specifically on a law enforcement officer. The opinion repeatedly states that the theft and subsequent shooting were a foreseeable consequence of negligent firearm storage, directly supporting that physical injury (and by implication its typical consequences such as medical expenses and lost wages) was a foreseeable risk of the negligent conduct.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.relevant_excerpt: In the instant case, Jupin argues that the theft of the handgun by Jason, and its subsequent use in the killing of a police officer, was a foreseeable consequence of Kask’s not ensuring the proper storage of firearms kept on her property, and that Kask thus owed the officer a duty of reasonable care. We agree that there was a duty of reasonable care in this case and find no public policy justification for refusing to impose it. … As in Pine Manor, the risk in the instant case — that a mentally unstable and violent person…would take a gun from that home and shoot someone — was both foreseeable and foreseen.

Glannon v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.raw_text: Glannon v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co., 387 Mass. 319, 323 (1982).
Glannon v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were not the result of any negligence on her part, but solely of Defendant’s failure to act as a reasonable person would under similar circumstances.
Glannon v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.case_name: Stratos v. Department of Public Welfare
Glannon v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Glannon v. Stop & Shop; it is Stratos v. Department of Public Welfare, a Massachusetts case about entitlement to attorneys’ fees under 42 U.S.C. § 1988 in a welfare-benefits dispute. The text concerns fee-shifting, § 1983 jurisdiction, and calculation of reasonable attorney’s fees, and does not address personal injury negligence, causation, or the absence of plaintiff’s contributory negligence. Therefore it cannot support the proposition about plaintiff’s injuries being solely due to defendant’s negligence.
Glannon v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.,.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that the judge was correct in his decision to award an attorney’s fee. We remand the case for further consideration by the judge of the proper fee for trial and appellate work by the plaintiff’s counsel.

Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.proposition: Defendant’s negligence caused Plaintiff to sustain physical pain, emotional distress, economic losses, and diminished enjoyment of life.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a social host who did not furnish alcohol owes a duty in negligence to third parties injured by an intoxicated guest. It does not involve findings that this defendant’s negligence caused a particular plaintiff to suffer physical pain, emotional distress, economic loss, or diminished enjoyment of life; rather, it holds that no common-law duty exists and affirms summary judgment for the defendant. Thus, it does not support the proposition about causation and specific categories of damages.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff claims that these circumstances impose a common law duty in negligence on the defendant for the protection of travelers on the highways.... We affirm the judgment.... Since no common law duty exists here, it follows that the statutes relied on by the plaintiff do not of themselves create a cause of action in tort. Judgment affirmed."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a76B.proposition: Award Plaintiff **costs and statutory interest** pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, §6B**;

Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.proposition: Pursuant to **Mass. R. Civ. P. 38**, Plaintiff hereby **demands a trial by jury** on all issues so triable.
